results.title: An Interview with Valda Maskell and Alf
results.creator_credit: Alfred Maskell, Valda Maskell and ACMI
results.brief_description: Valda Maskell, with the assistance of her husband Alfred, gives a touching account of how their love for each other survived World War 2. Valda met Alfred in Bendigo and they managed to get engaged just before Alfred was despatched to Malaya to fight the Japanese. The story is mostly told from Valda’s perspective, how she joined the RAAF and worked there as a cook and how she spent three years working there, all the while knowing nothing of Alfred’s fate. On his return, Valda promptly went AWOL, married Alfred and shares with us the ups and downs of her life with a returned soldier, who was also a prisoner of war.

results.title: ACMI moving family portraits
results.brief_description:
“Families of all shapes and sizes become part of a mammoth moving image mosaic…”
Created during an “open house” at Fed Square where photographs were taken, by Brett McLennan, of family groups and then projected live as a moving image photomontage.
In partnership with the LaTrobe University Bendigo Department of Visual Arts - Dr James McArdle, Prue Hawkey and Elysia Baker.

results.title: Metamorphs: 1st year Swinburne Multimedia Design Project
results.brief_description:
A selection of animated morphs created by nine students in their first year Multimedia course, Faculty of Design, Swinburne University of Technology.
The students are: Alicia Braumberger, Andrew Coles, Matthew Robinson, Michael Yates, Oliver Pauliczek, Reif Campling, Richard Osellame, Steven Donnet and Yudy Chainy.
Includes a single split-screen edited trailer and a full version of each of the nine morphs created by the students.

results.title: Modern Discoveries
results.brief_description:
A girl daydreams in class, thinking about people’s experiences of coming to Australia as well as her future desire to travel the world. Includes her thoughts about faraway societies.

An animated short entered to “Create a Stamp Story” section of ACMI’s ‘Screen It’ media making competition for Primary Schools.

results.title: Screen sports development workshop
results.creator_credit: Public Programs - Events (Helen Simondson) and Paul Fletcher
results.brief_description:
The SCREENSPORTS event is a unique, entertaining and informative ‘CINEMA EXPERIENCE’. SCREENSPORTS represents an historic leap in the marriage of live performance and technology. It has the potential to be an ACMI flagship pioneering new international standards in screen-based performance. Based on the highly successful Theatre Sports;live improvisation performance the Screensports concept draws on screen culture and the screen as the basis for live improvisation.

A troupe of actors are thrown into virtual worlds utilising the ACMI template sets and the globecaster technology. The actors use these sets as a stimulus for fast and hilarious improvisation.
Screen sports will be fun and informative and appeal to a wide range of people.
In order to develop the Screensports performance it is crucial to conduct a creative development workshop to produce the content for the live performance.

results.title: Pulse
results.brief_description: A series of silent epiphanies of night-time Melbourne. Young Melbourne filmmaker, Emma Sleath, has proposed a poignant and haunting series of tableaus for the ‘public imaging’ zones of the ground floor of ACMI.
results.description: A series of silent epiphanies of night-time Melbourne. Young Melbourne filmmaker, Emma Sleath, has proposed a poignant and haunting series of tableaus for the ‘public imaging’ zones of the ground floor of ACMI.

results.title: Heaven
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Surfing, sexuality and masculine bodies beneath the female gaze. A handheld camera closes in on private space of surfers as they disrobe in carparks and attempts to catch them ‘out’. Filmed in and around Sydney beaches, Moffatt and female friends have documented a playful but edgey representation of surfer culture as the interaction between the filmmaker and subject moves towards active voyerism. The heavy drum beats and lapping waves of the soundtrack mirror the thrill and excitement of gender mis-representation. How do the males react, or perform, on camera and how do audiences interpret their own voyeuristic desires? What does it suggest about the role of the film maker, of ethics or ‘surveillance’?

constellations_other.name: Flipping the gaze (Placeholder)
constellations_other.description: Steven Rhall's Avert considers how the white gaze has been trained on First Peoples and flips the surveillance by turning the camera on the viewer.

results.title: Corps flottant
results.brief_description: Cahen’s film is a video essay of a transitory reality depicted through the rhythms of rural life in Japan. Men bathe in the thermal springs of Kusatu, while an elderly woman tends to a rice paddy. Cahen creates a dream-like chronicle of the landscape and develops a painterly impression of the figures who exist within that landscape.

results.title: April 2nd, 1993
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Silver casts her female gaze onto a series of anonymous male subjects that she follows through the streets of the Marais district in Paris. The resulting `surveillance narrative,’ which features the music of Jo Privat, is an observation of viewing, power, and privacy in a public space.

results.title: Meet the People
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Blurring the line between documentary and fiction, truth and artifice, Meet the People presents fourteen ‘characters’ who face the camera in talking head close-ups and speak about their lives and dreams. The intimacy and honesty of their fragmented, autobiographical storytelling is illusory; the credits reveal that these people are professional actors, playing fictional roles, reading a script. As Silver writes, this work points to a complicity on the part of the viewer in his desire to believe and identify with the traditions of and characters on TV. The same television that mimics a perfected form of the identity of the ‘average person’ is also in part responsible for creating this identity; it both researches, uses and manufactures this ‘average person’s‘ hopes and dreams. And so the question of a ‘real person’ becomes ‘real’ compared to what?
